Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vast majority of people 
who’ve lost a limb can still feel it— not as a memory or vague shape,
but in complete lifelike detail. They can flex their phantom fingers and sometimes even feel 
the chafe of a watchband or the throb of an ingrown toenail. And astonishingly enough, occasionally even people born 
without a limb can feel a phantom. So what causes phantom limb sensations? The accuracy of these apparitions suggests that we have a map 
of the body in our brains. And the fact that it’s possible for someone who’s never had a limb 
to feel one implies we are born with at least 
the beginnings of this map. But one thing sets the phantoms
that appear after amputation apart from their flesh 
and blood predecessors: the vast majority of them are painful. To fully understand phantom limbs 
and phantom pain, we have to consider the entire pathway 
from limb to brain. Our limbs are full of sensory neurons
responsible for everything from the textures we feel 
with our fingertips to our understanding 
of where our bodies are in space. Neural pathways carry this sensory input
through the spinal cord and up to the brain. Since so much of this path 
lies outside the limb itself, most of it remains 
behind after an amputation. But the loss of a limb alters the way signals travel 
at every step of the pathway. At the site of an amputation, severed nerve endings can thicken 
and become more sensitive, transmitting distress signals 
even in response to mild pressure. Under normal circumstances, these signals would be curtailed 
in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. For reasons we don’t fully understand,
after an amputation, there is a loss of this inhibitory
control in the dorsal horn, and signals can intensify. Once they pass through the spinal cord,
sensory signals reach the brain. There, the somatosensory cortex 
processes them. The entire body is mapped in this cortex. Sensitive body parts 
with many nerve endings, like the lips and hands, are represented by the largest areas. The cortical homunculus is a model 
of the human body with proportions based on the size of each
body part’s representation in the cortex, The amount of cortex devoted 
to a specific body part can grow or shrink based on how much sensory input 
the brain receives from that body part. For example, representation of the left
hand is larger in violinists than in non-violinists. The brain also increases 
cortical representation when a body part is injured in order to heighten sensations 
that alert us to danger. This increased representation 
can lead to phantom pain. The cortical map is also 
most likely responsible for the feeling of body parts 
that are no longer there, because they still 
have representation in the brain. Over time, this representation may shrink
and the phantom limb may shrink with it. But phantom limb sensations 
don’t necessarily disappear on their own. Treatment for phantom pain 
usually requires a combination of physical therapy, medications for pain management, prosthetics, and time. A technique called mirror box therapy can be very helpful in developing 
the range of motion and reducing pain in the phantom limb. The patient places the phantom limb 
into a box behind a mirror and the intact limb 
in front of the mirror. This tricks the brain 
into seeing the phantom rather than just feeling it. Scientists are developing 
virtual reality treatments that make the experience 
of mirror box therapy even more lifelike. Prosthetics can also 
create a similar effect— many patients report pain primarily when they remove 
their prosthetics at night. And phantom limbs may in turn help patients conceptualize
prosthetics as extensions of their bodies and manipulate them intuitively. There are still many questions 
about phantom limbs. We don’t know why some amputees
escape the pain typically associated 
with these apparitions, or why some don’t have phantoms at all. And further research into phantom limbs isn’t just applicable to the people 
who experience them. A deeper understanding 
of these apparitions will give us insight into the work
our brains do every day to build the world as we perceive it. They’re an important reminder that the realities we experience are,
in fact, subjective.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The brain receives sensory input from the limbs via _______.
Options: A. Veins and the spinal cord, B. Nerves and the spinal cord, C. Bluetooth, D. Arteries and the spinal cord
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is a common phenomenon experienced by people who have lost a limb? Options: A. They can no longer feel sensations in the missing limb., B. They can feel the missing limb in complete lifelike detail., C. They experience temporary numbness in the remaining limbs., D. They have reduced sensitivity in the remaining limbs. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the name of the model that represents the human body with proportions based on the size of each body part's representation in the cortex? Options: A. Cortical homunculus, B. Somatosensory cortex, C. Phantom limb model, D. Neural pathway model Correct Option: None
Question 3: What happens to the representation of a body part in the cortex when it receives more sensory input? Options: A. It shrinks, B. It remains the same, C. It grows, D. It disappears Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is a possible explanation for the feeling of body parts that are no longer there? Options: A. The brain's inability to process sensory information, B. The presence of phantom limb sensations, C. The cortical map still having representation of the missing body part, D. The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the purpose of mirror box therapy in treating phantom pain? Options: A. To reduce pain by stimulating the intact limb, B. To trick the brain into seeing the phantom limb, C. To increase cortical representation of the missing limb, D. To decrease sensory input from the remaining limbs Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is a common experience reported by patients who use prosthetics? Options: A. They experience more pain when wearing prosthetics, B. They experience less pain when wearing prosthetics, C. They experience pain primarily when they remove their prosthetics at night, D. They experience no pain when wearing prosthetics Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the part of the brain that processes sensory signals from the body? Options: A. Somatosensory cortex, B. Dorsal horn, C. Cortical homunculus, D. Neural pathway Correct Option: None
Question 8: What happens to the severed nerve endings at the site of an amputation? Options: A. They become less sensitive, B. They remain the same, C. They thicken and become more sensitive, D. They disappear Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is a potential benefit of further research into phantom limbs? Options: A. It may lead to the development of more advanced prosthetics, B. It may provide insight into the work our brains do every day to build the world as we perceive it, C. It may lead to the discovery of a cure for phantom pain, D. It may result in a better understanding of the neural pathways involved in sensory perception Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is a characteristic of the phantom limbs experienced by people who have undergone an amputation? Options: A. They are usually painless, B. They are usually painful, C. They are experienced by only a few people, D. They are experienced by everyone who undergoes an amputation Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not explicitly listed. However, based on the content and intent of the ground truth MCQ, I can suggest that a new generated MCQ with the following content would be the most similar:

Question: The brain receives sensory input from the limbs via _______.
Options: A. Veins and the spinal cord, B. Nerves and the spinal cord, C. Arteries and the spinal cord, D. Neural pathways

However, if I had to choose from the existing generated MCQs, I would say that Question 7 is the most similar, as it mentions the part of the brain that processes sensory signals from the body, which is related to the pathway of sensory input from the limbs to the brain.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vast majority of people 
who’ve lost a limb can still feel it— not as a memory or vague shape,
but in complete lifelike detail. They can flex their phantom fingers and sometimes even feel 
the chafe of a watchband or the throb of an ingrown toenail. And astonishingly enough, occasionally even people born 
without a limb can feel a phantom. So what causes phantom limb sensations? The accuracy of these apparitions suggests that we have a map 
of the body in our brains. And the fact that it’s possible for someone who’s never had a limb 
to feel one implies we are born with at least 
the beginnings of this map. But one thing sets the phantoms
that appear after amputation apart from their flesh 
and blood predecessors: the vast majority of them are painful. To fully understand phantom limbs 
and phantom pain, we have to consider the entire pathway 
from limb to brain. Our limbs are full of sensory neurons
responsible for everything from the textures we feel 
with our fingertips to our understanding 
of where our bodies are in space. Neural pathways carry this sensory input
through the spinal cord and up to the brain. Since so much of this path 
lies outside the limb itself, most of it remains 
behind after an amputation. But the loss of a limb alters the way signals travel 
at every step of the pathway. At the site of an amputation, severed nerve endings can thicken 
and become more sensitive, transmitting distress signals 
even in response to mild pressure. Under normal circumstances, these signals would be curtailed 
in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. For reasons we don’t fully understand,
after an amputation, there is a loss of this inhibitory
control in the dorsal horn, and signals can intensify. Once they pass through the spinal cord,
sensory signals reach the brain. There, the somatosensory cortex 
processes them. The entire body is mapped in this cortex. Sensitive body parts 
with many nerve endings, like the lips and hands, are represented by the largest areas. The cortical homunculus is a model 
of the human body with proportions based on the size of each
body part’s representation in the cortex, The amount of cortex devoted 
to a specific body part can grow or shrink based on how much sensory input 
the brain receives from that body part. For example, representation of the left
hand is larger in violinists than in non-violinists. The brain also increases 
cortical representation when a body part is injured in order to heighten sensations 
that alert us to danger. This increased representation 
can lead to phantom pain. The cortical map is also 
most likely responsible for the feeling of body parts 
that are no longer there, because they still 
have representation in the brain. Over time, this representation may shrink
and the phantom limb may shrink with it. But phantom limb sensations 
don’t necessarily disappear on their own. Treatment for phantom pain 
usually requires a combination of physical therapy, medications for pain management, prosthetics, and time. A technique called mirror box therapy can be very helpful in developing 
the range of motion and reducing pain in the phantom limb. The patient places the phantom limb 
into a box behind a mirror and the intact limb 
in front of the mirror. This tricks the brain 
into seeing the phantom rather than just feeling it. Scientists are developing 
virtual reality treatments that make the experience 
of mirror box therapy even more lifelike. Prosthetics can also 
create a similar effect— many patients report pain primarily when they remove 
their prosthetics at night. And phantom limbs may in turn help patients conceptualize
prosthetics as extensions of their bodies and manipulate them intuitively. There are still many questions 
about phantom limbs. We don’t know why some amputees
escape the pain typically associated 
with these apparitions, or why some don’t have phantoms at all. And further research into phantom limbs isn’t just applicable to the people 
who experience them. A deeper understanding 
of these apparitions will give us insight into the work
our brains do every day to build the world as we perceive it. They’re an important reminder that the realities we experience are,
in fact, subjective.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The "map" of body parts in the somatosensory cortex _______.
Options: A. Grows or shrinks, based on how much sensory input the brain receives from that body part, B. Grows but never shrinks, based on how much sensory input the brain receives from that body part, C. Shrinks but never grows, based on how much sensory input the brain receives from that body part, D. Is hardwired from birth and never changes
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:

They can feel the missing limb in complete lifelike detail., C. They experience temporary numbness in the remaining limbs., D. They have reduced sensitivity in the remaining limbs. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the name of the model that represents the human body with proportions based on the size of each body part's representation in the cortex? Options: A. Cortical homunculus, B. Somatosensory cortex, C. Phantom limb model, D. Neural pathway model Correct Option: None

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent and content. Question 3 asks about the representation of a body part in the cortex and how it changes when it receives more sensory input. The correct answer for Question 3 is not explicitly provided, but based on the transcript, the correct answer would be C. It grows, which aligns with the correct answer for the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

even in response to mild pressure. Under normal circumstances, these signals would be curtailed

can lead to phantom pain. The cortical map is also

in fact, subjective.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In an attempt to modify this "map," mirror box therapy is where a patient _______.
Options: A. Stands inside a large box full of mirrors, B. Puts their intact limb behind a mirror, C. Puts their amputated limb behind a mirror, D. Puts both their intact and amputated limbs into a box with a mirror on one side
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is a common phenomenon experienced by people who have lost a limb? Options: A. They can no longer feel sensations in the missing limb., B. They can feel the missing limb in complete lifelike detail., C. They experience temporary numbness in the remaining limbs., D. They have reduced sensitivity in the remaining limbs. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the name of the model that represents the human body with proportions based on the size of each body part's representation in the cortex? Options: A. Cortical homunculus, B. Somatosensory cortex, C. Phantom limb model, D. Neural pathway model Correct Option: None
Question 3: What happens to the representation of a body part in the cortex when it receives more sensory input? Options: A. It shrinks, B. It remains the same, C. It grows, D. It disappears Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is a possible explanation for the feeling of body parts that are no longer there? Options: A. The brain's inability to process sensory information, B. The presence of phantom limb sensations, C. The cortical map still having representation of the missing body part, D. The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the purpose of mirror box therapy in treating phantom pain? Options: A. To reduce pain by stimulating the intact limb, B. To trick the brain into seeing the phantom limb, C. To increase cortical representation of the missing limb, D. To decrease sensory input from the remaining limbs Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is a common experience reported by patients who use prosthetics? Options: A. They experience more pain when wearing prosthetics, B. They experience less pain when wearing prosthetics, C. They experience pain primarily when they remove their prosthetics at night, D. They experience no pain when wearing prosthetics Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the part of the brain that processes sensory signals from the body? Options: A. Somatosensory cortex, B. Dorsal horn, C. Cortical homunculus, D. Neural pathway Correct Option: None
Question 8: What happens to the severed nerve endings at the site of an amputation? Options: A. They become less sensitive, B. They remain the same, C. They thicken and become more sensitive, D. They disappear Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is a potential benefit of further research into phantom limbs? Options: A. It may lead to the development of more advanced prosthetics, B. It may provide insight into the work our brains do every day to build the world as we perceive it, C. It may lead to the discovery of a cure for phantom pain, D. It may result in a better understanding of the neural pathways involved in sensory perception Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is a characteristic of the phantom limbs experienced by people who have undergone an amputation? Options: A. They are usually painless, B. They are usually painful, C. They are experienced by only a few people, D. They are experienced by everyone who undergoes an amputation Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

Here's why:

- Question intent: Both the ground truth MCQ and Question 5 are asking about mirror box therapy and its purpose or method.
- Options: Although the options are not identical, option B in Question 5 ("To trick the brain into seeing the phantom limb") is similar to the correct option C in the ground truth MCQ ("Puts their amputated limb behind a mirror"). Both options are related to the idea of using a mirror to create a visual representation of the phantom limb.
- Content: Both questions are discussing mirror box therapy, which is a key concept in the transcript related to phantom limbs and pain management.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 5.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do some amputees not have any phantom sensations?
Options: A. The nerves have been completely cut off, B. We don’t know yet, C. Because their cortical maps are broken, D. They have them but can’t feel them
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The vast majority of people 
who’ve lost a limb can still feel it— not as a memory or vague shape,
but in complete lifelike detail. They can flex their phantom fingers and sometimes even feel 
the chafe of a watchband or the throb of an ingrown toenail. And astonishingly enough, occasionally even people born 
without a limb can feel a phantom. So what causes phantom limb sensations? The accuracy of these apparitions suggests that we have a map 
of the body in our brains. And the fact that it’s possible for someone who’s never had a limb 
to feel one implies we are born with at least 
the beginnings of this map. But one thing sets the phantoms
that appear after amputation apart from their flesh 
and blood predecessors: the vast majority of them are painful. To fully understand phantom limbs 
and phantom pain, we have to consider the entire pathway 
from limb to brain. Our limbs are full of sensory neurons
responsible for everything from the textures we feel 
with our fingertips to our understanding 
of where our bodies are in space. Neural pathways carry this sensory input
through the spinal cord and up to the brain. Since so much of this path 
lies outside the limb itself, most of it remains 
behind after an amputation. But the loss of a limb alters the way signals travel 
at every step of the pathway. At the site of an amputation, severed nerve endings can thicken 
and become more sensitive, transmitting distress signals 
even in response to mild pressure. Under normal circumstances, these signals would be curtailed 
in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. For reasons we don’t fully understand,
after an amputation, there is a loss of this inhibitory
control in the dorsal horn, and signals can intensify. Once they pass through the spinal cord,
sensory signals reach the brain. There, the somatosensory cortex 
processes them. The entire body is mapped in this cortex. Sensitive body parts 
with many nerve endings, like the lips and hands, are represented by the largest areas. The cortical homunculus is a model 
of the human body with proportions based on the size of each
body part’s representation in the cortex, The amount of cortex devoted 
to a specific body part can grow or shrink based on how much sensory input 
the brain receives from that body part. For example, representation of the left
hand is larger in violinists than in non-violinists. The brain also increases 
cortical representation when a body part is injured in order to heighten sensations 
that alert us to danger. This increased representation 
can lead to phantom pain. The cortical map is also 
most likely responsible for the feeling of body parts 
that are no longer there, because they still 
have representation in the brain. Over time, this representation may shrink
and the phantom limb may shrink with it. But phantom limb sensations 
don’t necessarily disappear on their own. Treatment for phantom pain 
usually requires a combination of physical therapy, medications for pain management, prosthetics, and time. A technique called mirror box therapy can be very helpful in developing 
the range of motion and reducing pain in the phantom limb. The patient places the phantom limb 
into a box behind a mirror and the intact limb 
in front of the mirror. This tricks the brain 
into seeing the phantom rather than just feeling it. Scientists are developing 
virtual reality treatments that make the experience 
of mirror box therapy even more lifelike. Prosthetics can also 
create a similar effect— many patients report pain primarily when they remove 
their prosthetics at night. And phantom limbs may in turn help patients conceptualize
prosthetics as extensions of their bodies and manipulate them intuitively. There are still many questions 
about phantom limbs. We don’t know why some amputees
escape the pain typically associated 
with these apparitions, or why some don’t have phantoms at all. And further research into phantom limbs isn’t just applicable to the people 
who experience them. A deeper understanding 
of these apparitions will give us insight into the work
our brains do every day to build the world as we perceive it. They’re an important reminder that the realities we experience are,
in fact, subjective.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Phantom sensations raise the idea that bodily perceptions may be _______?
Options: A. Influenced by our environment, B. Influenced by memories, C. Influenced by movements, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is a common phenomenon experienced by people who have lost a limb? Options: A. They can no longer feel sensations in the missing limb., B. They can feel the missing limb in complete lifelike detail., C. They experience temporary numbness in the remaining limbs., D. They have reduced sensitivity in the remaining limbs. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the name of the model that represents the human body with proportions based on the size of each body part's representation in the cortex? Options: A. Cortical homunculus, B. Somatosensory cortex, C. Phantom limb model, D. Neural pathway model Correct Option: None
Question 3: What happens to the representation of a body part in the cortex when it receives more sensory input? Options: A. It shrinks, B. It remains the same, C. It grows, D. It disappears Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is a possible explanation for the feeling of body parts that are no longer there? Options: A. The brain's inability to process sensory information, B. The presence of phantom limb sensations, C. The cortical map still having representation of the missing body part, D. The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the purpose of mirror box therapy in treating phantom pain? Options: A. To reduce pain by stimulating the intact limb, B. To trick the brain into seeing the phantom limb, C. To increase cortical representation of the missing limb, D. To decrease sensory input from the remaining limbs Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is a common experience reported by patients who use prosthetics? Options: A. They experience more pain when wearing prosthetics, B. They experience less pain when wearing prosthetics, C. They experience pain primarily when they remove their prosthetics at night, D. They experience no pain when wearing prosthetics Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the part of the brain that processes sensory signals from the body? Options: A. Somatosensory cortex, B. Dorsal horn, C. Cortical homunculus, D. Neural pathway Correct Option: None
Question 8: What happens to the severed nerve endings at the site of an amputation? Options: A. They become less sensitive, B. They remain the same, C. They thicken and become more sensitive, D. They disappear Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is a potential benefit of further research into phantom limbs? Options: A. It may lead to the development of more advanced prosthetics, B. It may provide insight into the work our brains do every day to build the world as we perceive it, C. It may lead to the discovery of a cure for phantom pain, D. It may result in a better understanding of the neural pathways involved in sensory perception Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is a characteristic of the phantom limbs experienced by people who have undergone an amputation? Options: A. They are usually painless, B. They are usually painful, C. They are experienced by only a few people, D. They are experienced by everyone who undergoes an amputation Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the idea that phantom sensations raise regarding bodily perceptions. The closest generated MCQ that touches on this idea is Question 4, which asks about the possible explanation for the feeling of body parts that are no longer there.

Although Question 4 does not directly address the idea of bodily perceptions, it does relate to the concept of phantom sensations and how they are perceived by the brain. Therefore, I would suggest Question 4 as the most similar generated MCQ, albeit with some reservations due to the differences in question intent and options.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A portly Miller, barely sober enough
to sit on his horse, rambles on about the flighty wife 
of a crotchety old carpenter and the scholar she takes as her lover. To get some time alone together, the scholar and the wife 
play various tricks that involve feigning madness, staging a biblical flood, and exposing themselves in public. But the parish clerk 
is also lusting after the wife, and comes by every night 
to sing outside her house. This becomes so tiresome 
that she tries to scare him away by hanging her rear end out the window 
for him to kiss. When this appears not to work, her scholar decides 
to try farting in the same position, but this time, the clerk 
is waiting with a red-hot poker. This might all sound like a bawdy joke, but it’s part of one of the most esteemed 
works of English literature ever created: The Canterbury Tales, which seamlessly blends the lofty 
and the lowly. The work consists of 24 stories, each told by one 
of Chaucer’s spirited characters. Narrators include 
familiar Medieval figures such as a Knight, a Clerk, and a Nun, and the less recognizable Reeve, and Mancible, and others. The Tales are written in Middle English, which often looks entirely different 
from the language spoken today. It was used between the 12th 
and 15th centuries, and evolved from Old English due to increased contact 
with European romantic languages after the Norman Conquest of 1066. Most of the Middle English alphabet 
is still familiar today, with the inclusion 
of a few archaic symbols, such as yogh, which denotes the y, j, or gh sound. The loquacious cast of the Tales 
first meet at the Tabard Inn in Southwark. They have a journey in common: a pilgrimage to Canterbury 
to visit the shrine of St. Thomas Beckett, a martyred archbishop who was murdered 
in his own Cathedral. Eager and nosy
for some personal details, the host of the Inn 
proposes a competition: whoever tells the best tale 
will be treated to dinner. If not for their pilgrimage, many of these figures would never 
have had the chance to interact. This is because Medieval society followed 
a feudal system that divided the clergy and nobility 
from the working classes, made up of peasants and serfs. By Chaucer’s time, a professional class of merchants 
and intellectuals had also emerged. Chaucer spent most of his life 
as a government official during the Hundred Years' War, traveling throughout Italy and France,
as well as his native England. This may have influenced
the panoramic vision of his work, and in the Tales,
no level of society is above mockery. Chaucer uses the quirks 
of the characters’ language – the ribald humor of the Cook, the solemn prose of the Parson, and the lofty notions of the Squire – to satirize their worldviews. The varied dialects, genres, 
and literary tropes also make the work a vivid record of the different ways Medieval audiences 
entertained themselves. For instance, the Knight’s tale 
of courtly love, chivalry, and destiny riffs on romance, while the tales of working-class narrators
are generally comedies filled with scatological language, sexual deviance, and slapstick. This variation 
includes something for everyone, and that’s one reason why readers
continue to delight in the work in both Middle English and translation. While the narrative runs 
to over 17,000 lines, it's apparently unfinished, as the prologue ambitiously 
introduces 29 pilgrims and promises four stories apiece, and the innkeeper never crowns a victor. It’s possible that Chaucer was
so caught up in his sumptuous creations that he delayed picking a winner - or perhaps he was so fond 
of each character that he just couldn’t choose. Whatever the reason, this means that every reader
is free to judge; the question of who wins is up to you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Canterbury Tales is written in _______.
Options: A. Ancient English, B. Old English, C. Middle English, D. Modern English
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the author of "The Canterbury Tales"? Options: A. William Shakespeare, B. Geoffrey Chaucer, C. Jane Austen, D. Charles Dickens Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the name of the inn where the characters in "The Canterbury Tales" first meet? Options: A. The Red Lion, B. The Tabard Inn, C. The King's Head, D. The White Horse Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the destination of the pilgrimage in "The Canterbury Tales"? Options: A. Canterbury Cathedral, B. Westminster Abbey, C. St. Paul's Cathedral, D. The Tower of London Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the name of the martyred archbishop whose shrine the pilgrims are visiting? Options: A. St. Thomas Beckett, B. St. John the Baptist, C. St. George, D. St. Edward the Confessor Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the social system that divided Medieval society into different classes? Options: A. Feudalism, B. Capitalism, C. Socialism, D. Communism Correct Option: None
Question 6: How many stories are included in "The Canterbury Tales"? Options: A. 12, B. 24, C. 36, D. 48 Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the character who proposes a competition to tell the best tale? Options: A. The Host, B. The Knight, C. The Cook, D. The Parson Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the language in which "The Canterbury Tales" is written? Options: A. Old English, B. Middle English, C. Modern English, D. Latin Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the significance of the varied dialects, genres, and literary tropes in "The Canterbury Tales"? Options: A. They make the work a vivid record of Medieval history, B. They make the work a vivid record of the different ways Medieval audiences entertained themselves, C. They make the work a commentary on modern society, D. They make the work a critique of the feudal system Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is it possible that Chaucer never finished "The Canterbury Tales"? Options: A. He was dissatisfied with the work, B. He was too busy with other projects, C. He was so caught up in his creations that he delayed picking a winner, D. He lost interest in the project Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8: What is the language in which "The Canterbury Tales" is written? Options: A. Old English, B. Middle English, C. Modern English, D. Latin.

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the language in which "The Canterbury Tales" is written. The options are also similar, with the correct answer being Middle English.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
A portly Miller, barely sober enough
to sit on his horse, rambles on about the flighty wife 
of a crotchety old carpenter and the scholar she takes as her lover. To get some time alone together, the scholar and the wife 
play various tricks that involve feigning madness, staging a biblical flood, and exposing themselves in public. But the parish clerk

is waiting with a red-hot poker. This might all sound like a bawdy joke, but it’s part of one of the most esteemed

and 15th centuries, and evolved from Old English due to increased contact 
with European romantic languages after the Norman Conquest of 1066. Most of the Middle English alphabet 
is still familiar today, with the inclusion 
of a few archaic symbols, such as yogh, which denotes the y, j, or gh sound. The loquacious cast of the Tales 
first meet at the Tabard Inn in Southwark. They have a journey in common: a pilgrimage to Canterbury 
to visit the shrine of St. Thomas Beckett, a martyred archbishop who was murdered 
in his own Cathedral. Eager and nosy
for some personal details, the host of the Inn 
proposes a competition: whoever tells the best tale 
will be treated to dinner. If not for their pilgrimage, many of these figures would never 
have had the chance to interact. This is because Medieval society followed 
a feudal system that divided the clergy and nobility 
from the working classes, made up of peasants and serfs. By Chaucer’s time, a professional class of merchants 
and intellectuals had also emerged. Chaucer spent most of his life 
as a government official during the Hundred Years' War, traveling throughout Italy and France,
as well as his native England. This may have influenced
the panoramic vision of his work, and in the Tales,
no level of society is above mockery. Chaucer uses the quirks 
of the characters’ language – the ribald humor of the Cook, the solemn prose of the Parson, and the lofty notions of the Squire – to satirize their worldviews. The varied dialects, genres, 
and literary tropes also make the work a vivid record of the different ways Medieval audiences 
entertained themselves. For instance, the Knight’s tale 
of courtly love, chivalry, and destiny riffs on romance, while the tales of working-class narrators
are generally comedies filled with scatological language, sexual deviance, and slapstick. This variation 
includes something for everyone, and that’s one reason why readers
continue to delight in the work in both Middle English and translation. While the narrative runs 
to over 17,000 lines, it's apparently unfinished, as the prologue ambitiously 
introduces 29 pilgrims and promises four stories apiece, and the innkeeper never crowns a victor. It’s possible that Chaucer was
so caught up in his sumptuous creations that he delayed picking a winner - or perhaps he was so fond 
of each character that he just couldn’t choose. Whatever the reason, this means that every reader
is free to judge; the question of who wins is up to you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Characters include _______.
Options: A. A reeve, B. A nun, C. A king, D. A knight, E. A reeve, a nun, and a knight
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the author of "The Canterbury Tales"? Options: A. William Shakespeare, B. Geoffrey Chaucer, C. Jane Austen, D. Charles Dickens Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the name of the inn where the characters in "The Canterbury Tales" first meet? Options: A. The Red Lion, B. The Tabard Inn, C. The King's Head, D. The White Horse Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the destination of the pilgrimage in "The Canterbury Tales"? Options: A. Canterbury Cathedral, B. Westminster Abbey, C. St. Paul's Cathedral, D. The Tower of London Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the name of the martyred archbishop whose shrine the pilgrims are visiting? Options: A. St. Thomas Beckett, B. St. John the Baptist, C. St. George, D. St. Edward the Confessor Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the social system that divided Medieval society into different classes? Options: A. Feudalism, B. Capitalism, C. Socialism, D. Communism Correct Option: None
Question 6: How many stories are included in "The Canterbury Tales"? Options: A. 12, B. 24, C. 36, D. 48 Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the character who proposes a competition to tell the best tale? Options: A. The Host, B. The Knight, C. The Cook, D. The Parson Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the language in which "The Canterbury Tales" is written? Options: A. Old English, B. Middle English, C. Modern English, D. Latin Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the significance of the varied dialects, genres, and literary tropes in "The Canterbury Tales"? Options: A. They make the work a vivid record of Medieval history, B. They make the work a vivid record of the different ways Medieval audiences entertained themselves, C. They make the work a commentary on modern society, D. They make the work a critique of the feudal system Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is it possible that Chaucer never finished "The Canterbury Tales"? Options: A. He was dissatisfied with the work, B. He was too busy with other projects, C. He was so caught up in his creations that he delayed picking a winner, D. He lost interest in the project Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the characters in "The Canterbury Tales". While none of the generated MCQs ask the same question, Question 6 asks about the number of stories in "The Canterbury Tales" and mentions that each story is told by one of Chaucer's spirited characters.

However, a more suitable generated MCQ would be one that asks about the narrators or characters in the story. Unfortunately, none of the provided generated MCQs match this description.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar enough to be considered a match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A portly Miller, barely sober enough
to sit on his horse, rambles on about the flighty wife 
of a crotchety old carpenter and the scholar she takes as her lover. To get some time alone together, the scholar and the wife 
play various tricks that involve feigning madness, staging a biblical flood, and exposing themselves in public. But the parish clerk 
is also lusting after the wife, and comes by every night 
to sing outside her house. This becomes so tiresome 
that she tries to scare him away by hanging her rear end out the window 
for him to kiss. When this appears not to work, her scholar decides 
to try farting in the same position, but this time, the clerk 
is waiting with a red-hot poker. This might all sound like a bawdy joke, but it’s part of one of the most esteemed 
works of English literature ever created: The Canterbury Tales, which seamlessly blends the lofty 
and the lowly. The work consists of 24 stories, each told by one 
of Chaucer’s spirited characters. Narrators include 
familiar Medieval figures such as a Knight, a Clerk, and a Nun, and the less recognizable Reeve, and Mancible, and others. The Tales are written in Middle English, which often looks entirely different 
from the language spoken today. It was used between the 12th 
and 15th centuries, and evolved from Old English due to increased contact 
with European romantic languages after the Norman Conquest of 1066. Most of the Middle English alphabet 
is still familiar today, with the inclusion 
of a few archaic symbols, such as yogh, which denotes the y, j, or gh sound. The loquacious cast of the Tales 
first meet at the Tabard Inn in Southwark. They have a journey in common: a pilgrimage to Canterbury 
to visit the shrine of St. Thomas Beckett, a martyred archbishop who was murdered 
in his own Cathedral. Eager and nosy
for some personal details, the host of the Inn 
proposes a competition: whoever tells the best tale 
will be treated to dinner. If not for their pilgrimage, many of these figures would never 
have had the chance to interact. This is because Medieval society followed 
a feudal system that divided the clergy and nobility 
from the working classes, made up of peasants and serfs. By Chaucer’s time, a professional class of merchants 
and intellectuals had also emerged. Chaucer spent most of his life 
as a government official during the Hundred Years' War, traveling throughout Italy and France,
as well as his native England. This may have influenced
the panoramic vision of his work, and in the Tales,
no level of society is above mockery. Chaucer uses the quirks 
of the characters’ language – the ribald humor of the Cook, the solemn prose of the Parson, and the lofty notions of the Squire – to satirize their worldviews. The varied dialects, genres, 
and literary tropes also make the work a vivid record of the different ways Medieval audiences 
entertained themselves. For instance, the Knight’s tale 
of courtly love, chivalry, and destiny riffs on romance, while the tales of working-class narrators
are generally comedies filled with scatological language, sexual deviance, and slapstick. This variation 
includes something for everyone, and that’s one reason why readers
continue to delight in the work in both Middle English and translation. While the narrative runs 
to over 17,000 lines, it's apparently unfinished, as the prologue ambitiously 
introduces 29 pilgrims and promises four stories apiece, and the innkeeper never crowns a victor. It’s possible that Chaucer was
so caught up in his sumptuous creations that he delayed picking a winner - or perhaps he was so fond 
of each character that he just couldn’t choose. Whatever the reason, this means that every reader
is free to judge; the question of who wins is up to you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Canterbury Tales is a finished work.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When trains began to shuttle people 
across the coutryside, many insisted 
they would never replace horses. Less than a century later, people 
repeated that same prediction about cars, telephones, radio, television, and computers. Each had their own host of detractors. Even some experts 
insisted they wouldn’t catch on. Of course, we can’t predict exactly 
what the future will look like or what new inventions will populate it. But time and time again, we’ve also failed to predict 
that the technologies of the present will change the future. And recent research has revealed 
a similar pattern in our individual lives: we’re unable to predict change 
in ourselves. Three psychologists documented
our inability to predict personal change in a 2013 paper 
called, “The End of History Illusion.” Named after political scientist 
Francis Fukuyama’s prediction that liberal democracy 
was the final form of government, or as he called it, “the end of history,” their work highlights the way 
we see ourselves as finished products at any given moment. The researchers recruited over 
7,000 participants ages 18 to 68. They asked half of these participants to
report their current personality traits, values, and preferences, along with what each of those metrics 
had been ten years before. The other half described those features 
in their present selves, and predicted what 
they would be ten years in the future. Based on these answers, the researchers then calculated 
the degree of change each participant reported or predicted. For every age group in the sample, they compared the predicted changes 
to the reported changes. So they compared the degree to which 
18-year-olds thought they would change to the degree to which 28-year-olds 
reported they had changed. Overwhelmingly, at all ages, people’s future estimates of change 
came up short compared to the changes 
their older counterparts recalled. 20-year-olds expected 
to still like the same foods at 30, but 30-year-olds no longer 
had the same tastes. 30-year-olds predicted they’d still 
have the same best friend at 40, but 40-year-olds 
had lost touch with theirs. And 40-year-olds predicted 
they’d maintain the same core values that 50-year-olds had reconsidered. While older people changed less 
than younger people on the whole, they underestimated 
their capacity for change just as much. Wherever we are in life,
the end of history illusion persists: we tend to think that the bulk 
of our personal change is behind us. One consequence of this thinking is that we’re inclined to overinvest 
in future choices based on present preferences. On average, people are willing 
to pay about 60% more to see their current favorite musician 
ten years in the future than they’d currently pay to see their 
favorite musician from ten years ago. While the stakes involved
in concert-going are low, we’re susceptible 
to similar miscalculations in more serious commitments, like homes, partners, and jobs. At the same time, 
there’s no real way to predict what our preferences 
will be in the future. Without the end of history Illusion, it would be difficult 
to make any long-term plans. So the end of history illusion 
applies to our individual lives, but what about the wider world? Could we be assuming that how things 
are now is how they will continue to be? If so, fortunately,
there are countless records to remind us that the world does change,
sometimes for the better. Our own historical moment 
isn’t the end of history, and that can be just as much a source
of comfort as a cause for concern.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When was the research paper discussed in this lesson published?
Options: A. 1983, B. 1993, C. 2003, D. 2013
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main idea behind the concept of "The End of History Illusion"? Options: A. That people tend to overestimate their ability to predict future change, B. That people tend to underestimate their ability to predict future change, C. That people tend to think that the bulk of their personal change is behind them, D. That people tend to overinvest in future choices based on past preferences Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to the researchers, what is the primary consequence of the "End of History Illusion"? Options: A. We tend to overestimate our capacity for change, B. We tend to underestimate our capacity for change, C. We tend to overinvest in future choices based on present preferences, D. We tend to make more informed decisions about our future Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the method used by the researchers to study the "End of History Illusion"? Options: A. They asked participants to report their current personality traits and predict what they would be in ten years, B. They asked participants to report their current personality traits and what they had been ten years before, C. They asked half of the participants to report their current personality traits and what they had been ten years before, and the other half to describe their present selves and predict what they would be in ten years, D. They asked participants to report their current personality traits and compare them to their parents' traits Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the name of the political scientist whose prediction inspired the title "The End of History Illusion"? Options: A. Francis Fukuyama, B. Sigmund Freud, C. Albert Einstein, D. Charles Darwin Correct Option: None
Question 5: According to the study, what is the average amount that people are willing to pay to see their current favorite musician ten years in the future compared to their favorite musician from ten years ago? Options: A. 20% more, B. 40% more, C. 60% more, D. 80% more Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the age range of the participants in the study? Options: A. 18-30 years old, B. 18-40 years old, C. 18-50 years old, D. 18-68 years old Correct Option: None
Question 7: According to the study, which age group tends to change less than younger people? Options: A. 20-30 years old, B. 30-40 years old, C. 40-50 years old, D. Older people (in general) Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the main idea behind the comparison of the predicted changes to the reported changes in the study? Options: A. To show that people tend to overestimate their ability to predict future change, B. To show that people tend to underestimate their ability to predict future change, C. To show that people tend to think that the bulk of their personal change is behind them, D. To show that people tend to make more informed decisions about their future Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the consequence of not having the "End of History Illusion"? Options: A. We would make more informed decisions about our future, B. We would tend to overinvest in future choices based on present preferences, C. We would be more open to new experiences, D. It would be difficult to make any long-term plans Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main idea behind the application of the "End of History Illusion" to the wider world? Options: A. That we should assume that how things are now is how they will continue to be, B. That we should be aware that the world does change and that our current moment is not the end of history, C. That we should overinvest in future choices based on present preferences, D. That we should make more informed decisions about our future Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. However, I can suggest that the generated MCQs do not include a question about the publication year of the research paper.

If I had to choose a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ, I would say that Question 4 is the closest, but only because it mentions the name of the political scientist whose prediction inspired the title "The End of History Illusion", and the ground truth MCQ mentions the year the research paper was published, which is related to the same topic. However, the question intent, options, and content are still quite different.

Therefore, I would say that there is no generated MCQ that closely matches the ground truth MCQ.

Index: None

across the coutryside, many insisted

of our personal change is behind us. One consequence of this thinking is that we’re inclined to overinvest 
in future choices based on present preferences. On average, people are willing 
to pay about 60% more to see their current favorite musician 
ten years in the future than they’d currently pay to see their 
favorite musician from ten years ago. While the stakes involved
in concert-going are low, we’re susceptible 
to similar miscalculations in more serious commitments, like homes, partners, and jobs. At the same time, 
there’s no real way to predict what our preferences 
will be in the future. Without the end of history Illusion, it would be difficult 
to make any long-term plans. So the end of history illusion 
applies to our individual lives, but what about the wider world? Could we be assuming that how things 
are now is how they will continue to be? If so, fortunately,
there are countless records to remind us that the world does change,
sometimes for the better. Our own historical moment 
isn’t the end of history, and that can be just as much a source
of comfort as a cause for concern.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which age group is the least susceptible to changes?
Options: A. Young people, B. Middle aged people, C. Elderly people, D. No difference
Correct Option: C

That people tend to overinvest in future choices based on past preferences Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When trains began to shuttle people 
across the coutryside, many insisted 
they would never replace horses. Less than a century later, people 
repeated that same prediction about cars, telephones, radio, television, and computers. Each had their own host of detractors. Even some experts 
insisted they wouldn’t catch on. Of course, we can’t predict exactly 
what the future will look like or what new inventions will populate it. But time and time again, we’ve also failed to predict 
that the technologies of the present will change the future. And recent research has revealed 
a similar pattern in our individual lives: we’re unable to predict change 
in ourselves. Three psychologists documented
our inability to predict personal change in a 2013 paper 
called, “The End of History Illusion.” Named after political scientist 
Francis Fukuyama’s prediction that liberal democracy 
was the final form of government, or as he called it, “the end of history,” their work highlights the way 
we see ourselves as finished products at any given moment. The researchers recruited over 
7,000 participants ages 18 to 68. They asked half of these participants to
report their current personality traits, values, and preferences, along with what each of those metrics 
had been ten years before. The other half described those features 
in their present selves, and predicted what 
they would be ten years in the future. Based on these answers, the researchers then calculated 
the degree of change each participant reported or predicted. For every age group in the sample, they compared the predicted changes 
to the reported changes. So they compared the degree to which 
18-year-olds thought they would change to the degree to which 28-year-olds 
reported they had changed. Overwhelmingly, at all ages, people’s future estimates of change 
came up short compared to the changes 
their older counterparts recalled. 20-year-olds expected 
to still like the same foods at 30, but 30-year-olds no longer 
had the same tastes. 30-year-olds predicted they’d still 
have the same best friend at 40, but 40-year-olds 
had lost touch with theirs. And 40-year-olds predicted 
they’d maintain the same core values that 50-year-olds had reconsidered. While older people changed less 
than younger people on the whole, they underestimated 
their capacity for change just as much. Wherever we are in life,
the end of history illusion persists: we tend to think that the bulk 
of our personal change is behind us. One consequence of this thinking is that we’re inclined to overinvest 
in future choices based on present preferences. On average, people are willing 
to pay about 60% more to see their current favorite musician 
ten years in the future than they’d currently pay to see their 
favorite musician from ten years ago. While the stakes involved
in concert-going are low, we’re susceptible 
to similar miscalculations in more serious commitments, like homes, partners, and jobs. At the same time, 
there’s no real way to predict what our preferences 
will be in the future. Without the end of history Illusion, it would be difficult 
to make any long-term plans. So the end of history illusion 
applies to our individual lives, but what about the wider world? Could we be assuming that how things 
are now is how they will continue to be? If so, fortunately,
there are countless records to remind us that the world does change,
sometimes for the better. Our own historical moment 
isn’t the end of history, and that can be just as much a source
of comfort as a cause for concern.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the End of History Illusion about?
Options: A. The relation between actual and perceived past changes, B. The relation between actual and expected future changes, C. The relation between past and future changes, D. Liberal democracy
Correct Option: B

across the coutryside, many insisted 
they would never replace horses. Less than a century later, people 
repeated that same prediction about cars, telephones, radio, television, and computers. Each had their own host of detractors. Even some experts

sometimes for the better. Our own historical moment 
isn’t the end of history, and that can be just as much a source
of comfort as a cause for concern.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A high forehead topped 
by disheveled black hair, a sickly pallor, and a look of deep intelligence 
and deeper exhaustion in his dark, sunken eyes. Edgar Allan Poe’s image 
is not just instantly recognizable – it’s perfectly suited to his reputation. From the prisoner strapped 
under a descending pendulum blade, to a raven who refuses 
to leave the narrator’s chamber, Poe’s macabre and innovative stories 
of gothic horror have left a timeless mark on literature. But just what is it that makes
Edgar Allan Poe one of the greatest American authors? After all, horror was a popular
genre of the period, with many practitioners. Yet Poe stood out thanks to his
careful attention to form and style. As a literary critic, he identified two cardinal rules 
for the short story form: it must be short enough 
to read in one sitting, and every word 
must contribute to its purpose. By mastering these rules, Poe commands the reader’s attention and rewards them with an intense 
and singular experience – what Poe called the unity of effect. Though often frightening,
this effect goes far beyond fear. Poe’s stories use violence and horror
to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt, while resisting simple interpretations 
or clear moral messages. And while they often hint 
at supernatural elements, the true darkness they explore
is the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction. In “The Tell-Tale Heart,”
a ghastly murder is juxtaposed with the killer’s 
tender empathy towards the victim – a connection that soon 
returns to haunt him. The title character of "Ligeia"
returns from the dead through the corpse 
of her husband’s second wife – or at least the opium-addicted 
narrator thinks she does. And when the protagonist 
of “William Wilson” violently confronts a man 
he believes has been following him, he might just be staring 
at his own image in a mirror. Through his pioneering use 
of unreliable narrators, Poe turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller
might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events 
they’re relating. Although he’s best known 
for his short horror stories, Poe was actually one of the most versatile and experimental writers 
of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social 
and literary trends, and hoaxes that in some cases 
anticipated science fiction. Those included an account of 
a balloon voyage to the moon, and a report of a dying patient 
put into a hypnotic trance so he could speak from the other side. Poe even wrote an adventure novel 
about a voyage to the South Pole and a treatise on astrophysics, all while he worked as an editor, producing hundreds of pages 
of book reviews and literary theory. An appreciation of Poe’s career 
wouldn’t be complete without his poetry: haunting and hypnotic. His best-known poems are songs of grief, 
or in his words, “mournful and never-ending remembrance.” “The Raven,” in which the speaker 
projects his grief onto a bird who merely repeats a single sound, made Poe famous. But despite his literary success, Poe lived in poverty 
throughout his career, and his personal life was often 
as dark as his writing. He was haunted by the loss of his mother 
and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which phrase best sums up Poe’s guiding principle for writing fiction?
Options: A. Shock and awe, B. Unity of effect, C. The iceberg principle, D. Deep hidden meaning
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is one of the key features that makes Edgar Allan Poe's image instantly recognizable? Options: A. His bright smile, B. His disheveled black hair and sunken eyes, C. His tall stature, D. His bright blue eyes Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to Poe, what are the two cardinal rules for the short story form? Options: A. It must be long and every word must contribute to its purpose, B. It must be short enough to read in one sitting and every word must contribute to its purpose, C. It must be written in first person and every word must contribute to its purpose, D. It must be written in third person and every word must contribute to its purpose Correct Option: None
Question 3: What effect does Poe aim to achieve through his stories, which goes beyond fear? Options: A. The unity of effect, B. The horror of death, C. The mystery of love, D. The power of guilt Correct Option: None
Question 4: In "The Tell-Tale Heart," what is juxtaposed with the killer's violent act? Options: A. The victim's anger, B. The killer's tender empathy towards the victim, C. The police investigation, D. The narrator's madness Correct Option: None
Question 5: What literary device did Poe pioneer in his stories? Options: A. Unreliable narrators, B. Stream-of-consciousness narration, C. Magical realism, D. Symbolism Correct Option: None
Question 6: What genre of story did Poe invent with "The Murders in the Rue Morgue"? Options: A. Science fiction, B. Detective story, C. Romance novel, D. Historical fiction Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the detective in Poe's stories, who uses his genius and powers of observation to solve crimes? Options: A. C. Auguste Dupin, B. Sherlock Holmes, C. Hercule Poirot, D. Inspector Morse Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the theme of many of Poe's poems, including "The Raven"? Options: A. Love and joy, B. Grief and remembrance, C. Nature and beauty, D. Life and hope Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was a major struggle in Poe's personal life? Options: A. Poverty and loss of loved ones, B. Fame and wealth, C. Marriage and relationships, D. Health and wellness Correct Option: None
Question 10: When did much of Poe's fame come, in relation to his lifetime? Options: A. During his lifetime, B. Immediately after his death, C. Posthumously, through loose adaptations of his work, D. Not at all Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: What effect does Poe aim to achieve through his stories, which goes beyond fear? Options: A. The unity of effect, B. The horror of death, C. The mystery of love, D. The power of guilt.

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it asks about Poe's guiding principle for writing fiction, which is the "unity of effect." Although the question is phrased differently, the correct answer is the same as the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social 
and literary trends, and hoaxes that in some cases 
anticipated science fiction. Those included an account of 
a balloon voyage to the moon, and a report of a dying patient 
put into a hypnotic trance so he could speak from the other side. Poe even wrote an adventure novel 
about a voyage to the South Pole and a treatise on astrophysics, all while he worked as an editor, producing hundreds of pages 
of book reviews and literary theory. An appreciation of Poe’s career 
wouldn’t be complete without his poetry: haunting and hypnotic. His best-known poems are songs of grief, 
or in his words, “mournful and never-ending remembrance.” “The Raven,” in which the speaker 
projects his grief onto a bird who merely repeats a single sound, made Poe famous. But despite his literary success, Poe lived in poverty 
throughout his career, and his personal life was often 
as dark as his writing. He was haunted by the loss of his mother 
and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In which of these literary genres did Poe not publish?
Options: A. Epic poem, B. Adventure novel, C. Satire, D. Detective fiction
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is one of the key features that makes Edgar Allan Poe's image instantly recognizable? Options: A. His bright smile, B. His disheveled black hair and sunken eyes, C. His tall stature, D. His bright blue eyes Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to Poe, what are the two cardinal rules for the short story form? Options: A. It must be long and every word must contribute to its purpose, B. It must be short enough to read in one sitting and every word must contribute to its purpose, C. It must be written in first person and every word must contribute to its purpose, D. It must be written in third person and every word must contribute to its purpose Correct Option: None
Question 3: What effect does Poe aim to achieve through his stories, which goes beyond fear? Options: A. The unity of effect, B. The horror of death, C. The mystery of love, D. The power of guilt Correct Option: None
Question 4: In "The Tell-Tale Heart," what is juxtaposed with the killer's violent act? Options: A. The victim's anger, B. The killer's tender empathy towards the victim, C. The police investigation, D. The narrator's madness Correct Option: None
Question 5: What literary device did Poe pioneer in his stories? Options: A. Unreliable narrators, B. Stream-of-consciousness narration, C. Magical realism, D. Symbolism Correct Option: None
Question 6: What genre of story did Poe invent with "The Murders in the Rue Morgue"? Options: A. Science fiction, B. Detective story, C. Romance novel, D. Historical fiction Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the detective in Poe's stories, who uses his genius and powers of observation to solve crimes? Options: A. C. Auguste Dupin, B. Sherlock Holmes, C. Hercule Poirot, D. Inspector Morse Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the theme of many of Poe's poems, including "The Raven"? Options: A. Love and joy, B. Grief and remembrance, C. Nature and beauty, D. Life and hope Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was a major struggle in Poe's personal life? Options: A. Poverty and loss of loved ones, B. Fame and wealth, C. Marriage and relationships, D. Health and wellness Correct Option: None
Question 10: When did much of Poe's fame come, in relation to his lifetime? Options: A. During his lifetime, B. Immediately after his death, C. Posthumously, through loose adaptations of his work, D. Not at all Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

The correct option in the ground truth MCQ is "Epic poem" (as the genre Poe did not publish in), and in Question 6, the correct option is "B. Detective story" (as the genre Poe invented). Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A high forehead topped 
by disheveled black hair, a sickly pallor, and a look of deep intelligence 
and deeper exhaustion in his dark, sunken eyes. Edgar Allan Poe’s image 
is not just instantly recognizable – it’s perfectly suited to his reputation. From the prisoner strapped 
under a descending pendulum blade, to a raven who refuses 
to leave the narrator’s chamber, Poe’s macabre and innovative stories 
of gothic horror have left a timeless mark on literature. But just what is it that makes
Edgar Allan Poe one of the greatest American authors? After all, horror was a popular
genre of the period, with many practitioners. Yet Poe stood out thanks to his
careful attention to form and style. As a literary critic, he identified two cardinal rules 
for the short story form: it must be short enough 
to read in one sitting, and every word 
must contribute to its purpose. By mastering these rules, Poe commands the reader’s attention and rewards them with an intense 
and singular experience – what Poe called the unity of effect. Though often frightening,
this effect goes far beyond fear. Poe’s stories use violence and horror
to explore the paradoxes and mysteries of love, grief, and guilt, while resisting simple interpretations 
or clear moral messages. And while they often hint 
at supernatural elements, the true darkness they explore
is the human mind and its propensity for self-destruction. In “The Tell-Tale Heart,”
a ghastly murder is juxtaposed with the killer’s 
tender empathy towards the victim – a connection that soon 
returns to haunt him. The title character of "Ligeia"
returns from the dead through the corpse 
of her husband’s second wife – or at least the opium-addicted 
narrator thinks she does. And when the protagonist 
of “William Wilson” violently confronts a man 
he believes has been following him, he might just be staring 
at his own image in a mirror. Through his pioneering use 
of unreliable narrators, Poe turns readers into active participants who must decide when a storyteller
might be misinterpreting or even lying about the events 
they’re relating. Although he’s best known 
for his short horror stories, Poe was actually one of the most versatile and experimental writers 
of the nineteenth century. He invented the detective story 
as we know it, with “The Murders in the Rue Morgue,” followed by “The Mystery of Marie Roget” and “The Purloined Letter.” All three feature 
the original armchair detective, C. Auguste Dupin, who uses his genius and unusual powers 
of observation and deduction to solve crimes that baffle the police. Poe also wrote satires of social 
and literary trends, and hoaxes that in some cases 
anticipated science fiction. Those included an account of 
a balloon voyage to the moon, and a report of a dying patient 
put into a hypnotic trance so he could speak from the other side. Poe even wrote an adventure novel 
about a voyage to the South Pole and a treatise on astrophysics, all while he worked as an editor, producing hundreds of pages 
of book reviews and literary theory. An appreciation of Poe’s career 
wouldn’t be complete without his poetry: haunting and hypnotic. His best-known poems are songs of grief, 
or in his words, “mournful and never-ending remembrance.” “The Raven,” in which the speaker 
projects his grief onto a bird who merely repeats a single sound, made Poe famous. But despite his literary success, Poe lived in poverty 
throughout his career, and his personal life was often 
as dark as his writing. He was haunted by the loss of his mother 
and his wife, who both died of tuberculosis 
at the age of 24. Poe struggled with alcoholism and frequently antagonized 
other popular writers. Much of his fame came from posthumous –
and very loose – adaptations of his work. And yet, if he could’ve known 
how much pleasure and inspiration his writing would bring to generations
of readers and writers alike, perhaps it may have brought 
a smile to that famously brooding visage.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these figures is a character created by Poe?
Options: A. Robinson Crusoe, B. C. Auguste Dupin, C. Sherlock Holmes, D. Jane Eyre
Correct Option: B

It must be written in third person and every word must contribute to its purpose Correct Option: None

a smile to that famously brooding visage.
